title.value: Patterns of connectome variability in autism across five functional activation tasks: findings from the LEAP project
title.justification: The title captures the main focus of the research which is to study connectivity patterns in autism using multiple functional activation tasks.
title.quote: Patterns of connectome variability in autism across five functional activation tasks: findings from the LEAP project

extractions.description: The paper investigates the variability of brain connectivity in individuals with autism across different functional tasks using fMRI data from the LEAP project. It employs novel approaches like task potency and normative modeling to assess individual-level neural atypicalities and their relationship with autism-related behaviors.

type.justification: The study involves empirical analysis of fMRI data across different tasks to understand connectivity patterns in autism.
type.quote: Methods: All analyses were based on the EU-AIMS/AIMS-2-TRIALS multisite Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP) with participants with autism (n = 282) and typically developing (TD) controls (n = 221) between 6 and 30 years of age.

name.justification: The research field is focused on brain connectivity patterns in autism, which falls under neuroscience.
name.quote: Background: Autism spectrum disorder (autism) is a complex neurodevelopmental condition with pronounced behavioral, cognitive, and neural heterogeneities across individuals.

name.justification: The study uses fMRI data to analyze brain connectivity in individuals with autism.
name.quote: Background: We employed a novel task potency approach which combines the unique aspects of both resting state fMRI and task-fMRI to quantify task-induced variations in the functional connectome.

name.justification: The study focuses specifically on brain connectivity patterns in individuals with autism.
name.quote: Background: Autism spectrum disorder (autism) is a complex neurodevelopmental condition with pronounced behavioral, cognitive, and neural heterogeneities across individuals.

name.justification: The paper mentions using CCA to relate connectome data to behavioral data, making it a central model used in this research.
name.quote: We applied robust out-of-sample canonical correlation analysis (CCA) to relate connectome data to behavioral data.

is_contributed.justification: CCA is an existing statistical method, not contributed by this paper.
is_contributed.quote: We applied robust out-of-sample canonical correlation analysis (CCA) to relate connectome data to behavioral data.

is_executed.justification: The study executed CCA to analyze data, indicating it was utilized practically in the research.
is_executed.quote: We applied robust out-of-sample canonical correlation analysis (CCA) to relate connectome data to behavioral data.

is_compared.justification: The paper does not mention any numerical comparison of CCA to other models within the scope of the research.
is_compared.quote: We applied robust out-of-sample canonical correlation analysis (CCA) to relate connectome data to behavioral data.

referenced_paper_title.value: Relations between two sets of variates
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the original paper on CCA by Hotelling, providing a relevant reference for the model.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Canonical correlation analysis (CCA) is a technique for finding latent linear multivariate relationships between two sets of data [48–50].

name.justification: The LEAP project data is central to the study's analyses of autism.
name.quote: Methods: All analyses were based on the EU-AIMS/AIMS-2-TRIALS multisite Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP) with participants with autism (n = 282) and typically developing (TD) controls (n = 221) between 6 and 30 years of age.

referenced_paper_title.value: The EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP): methods
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is part of the reference list as a source describing the LEAP dataset methods.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP): methods. Mol Autism. 2017;8:1–19.

name.justification: The paper mentions using FSL for preprocessing fMRI data, indicating its use in the research.
name.quote: Preprocessing of both the resting state- and task-fMRI data was performed with tools from FSL [35].

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper cites FSL as a major tool used for data analysis and preprocessing.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Jenkinson M, Beckmann CF, Behrens TEJ, Woolrich MW, Smith SM. FSL. Neuroimage. 2012;62:782–90.
